ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Summary: This class introduces the major thinkers and theories of religion and how to study it from the 20th century -- essential for anyone hoping to be able to teach on the subject some day.Recommendation: You need to know these thinkers, and this is the best way to do it.

The course was essentially a guided reading group through some of the classic works and issues in the theory of religion. I would recommend it to all students of religion, since it helps frame many of the issues they will confront every day.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: Little to dissertation/research, since "religion" doesn't relate heavily to it in a conceptually direct way; but absolutely necessary and helpful for being in the profession/discipline.

This course is one of thefew opportunities for students in the Department of Religious Studies to access the theory of religion. It provided essential tools to understand, evaluate and critique other works of scholarship in the students' respective fields, and also encouraged students to support their work with a theoretical framework.
